context: The addition of L-methionine to the growth medium resulted in the production of several VOCs, including methylamine. This simple amine might be the product of several microbial metabolic reactions; therefore we explored the metabolic routes used by P. haloplanktis TAC125 to produce methylamine when growing on GGM medium. The genome of P. haloplanktis TAC125 was in silico analysed looking for the intracellular L-methionine destiny (data not shown), and this analysis revealed the absence of the genes encoding some key enzymes involved in previously reported L-methionine degradation pathways. These findings suggest that L-methionine catabolism of P. haloplanktis TAC125 offers several aspects of novelty thus supporting the idea that P. haloplanktis TAC125 evolved unknown metabolic routes for the use of this amino acid, some of which may end up with the production of methylamine. It is interesting to note that almost 11% of the protein encoding genes identified in P. haloplanktis TAC125 genome have still no homologous in any other organism. Even though methylamine was never identified amongst the VOCs released by P. haloplanktis TAC125 when grown in complex media, we focused our attention on it, since the antimicrobial activity of this amine was never reported. Methylamine is able to inhibit the growth of several Bcc strains at different concentrations by a still unknown mode of action, not related to a nonspecific pH increase.
